Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: When there was no homework 0-4hours per week; when I had homework, it probably took me up to 24 hours of working time to fully research and write; for exam week, I spent probably 15 hours reviewing.
If there was an assignment (only three weeks of the semester), I would spend 2-4 hours. If no assignment, I spent 0 hours outside of the classroom.
Varied a lot - sometimes none/1 hour, but on weeks where we had an assignment, 6-8. Exam weeks probably around 10.
During weeks with homework assignments, approximately 5 hours. During exam weeks, approximately 5-10 hours.
1 hour

Strengths: multiple lecturers. Having experts is invaluable.
Open-ended assignments and exams. Forces students to truly think about the issues at hand rather than just regurgitate answers.

Weaknesses:
There were a lot of readings that seemed more "interesting" rather than "necessary" in terms of what we needed to know for exams. Demarcating personal interest vs. exam material could be of help for busy Yalies.

I thought this was poorly done. The instructor was un-engaging, and said a lot of questionable things. Did not explain things well. Was difficult to understand. After the midterm he basically told us we all were horrible students and should have tried harder. But when you have an exam average in the 70s, then something is wrong with the exam or the way it was taught. There were many visiting lecturers which made it difficult to get in a rhythm or know what was going to be on the exam.

Strengths: Jamie Childs is a wonderful instructor with so much experience, and an interesting person. The variety in topics keeps it interesting.
Weaknesses: It was somewhat unclear going into the first exam what exactly it would be like, and what the best way to prepare was; I think that the assignments might be better as shorter weekly/biweekly assignments.

The course could do well with more/different organization and trimming. It felt like a lot of random information put together from different subject areas for one pathogen. For example, we talked about molecular biology, immunology, medicine, policy, ecology, etc for every pathogen. 

Although the writing assignments were interesting, it would have been nice to have more variety in the topic and maybe a little more related to course content.
Poorly organized material, vague exam and homework questions but the expectation of very specific answers

Strengths = interesting topics
Weaknesses = Could have responded to questions quicker and post the homework on time.
Loved the class! Will miss Prof. Childs next year!!

Fine but the grading is absurd. Professor is retiring so guess not much to say, but come on... open ended lectures with a line up on guest speakers and then you drop assessments with such a high expectation. Not good.

I think the strengths of the course were having speakers that were experts in the topics being discussed.  Ways in which the course could be improved could include having more time for open discussion on the topics.
I like the topics that the class covered, but it was just a bit disorganized in general.

Having so many guest lecturers was awful. The constantly changing teaching style makes it hard to learn. Also some were just awful instructors and some were very problematic. The majority of public health students are female. We should not have a majority old white male guest lecturers. Yes they are experts but I KNOW there are women and people of color available to guest lecture. Representation is crucial especially at Yale. We don't need a guest lecture for every topic. That just turns into a seminar and not a course.

There were some great concepts taught in this class but the way they were taught was occasionally very confusing with different speakers often coming in. While  the different speakers  provided specialized information it was difficult to know what material would be needed to know for exams and lacked organization to study. I did really enjoying learning about zoonotic and vector borne diseases and how we should approach these in a public health setting.

I really enjoyed the topics we covered in this course and I like Dr. Childs, but I think it was difficult to know how to succeed in this course. Many lectures were given by different teachers which made things more interesting but definitely more difficult to know what parts would be important for exams.
Learned about a wide variety of different infectious diseases.

He's retiring, does this feedback matter anymore?! 

But in all honesty, Dr. Childs is a phenomenal professor. He treats his students like adults, which I totally appreciate. I've known professors to hound their students for circumstances that may be out of their control, while Dr. Childs is understanding about personal situations as well as honest when he's dissatisfied with our performance. He has high expectations but also gives us the benefit of the doubt.

Jamie knows a lot of stuff, but he is not a good lecturer. He goes on rants and changes subjects and gets off topic easily and regularly. He said things that were both insulting to students and people of different countries when talking about international work. Often times when asked a question, he wouldn't or couldn't directly give an answer even when it was on the subject material.
Jamie is one of the most interesting and cool instructors at YSPH. His experience and demeanor make him great for teaching.

More clearly organized lecturing style would be better, tended to ramble a little bit and was hard to follow
Better use of visuals
He's fantastic, sorry to see him leave
I really enjoyed hearing about his own experiences in the field, and how he tied them into lecture!
good guy, best of luck in retirement.
Professor Childs is very passionate about what he teaches and is very supportive of students.  He encourages questions and is overall, a very welcoming and down to earth professor.

Dr. Childs clearly knows a great deal of information and has a lot of first hand experience in these diseases that made lectures interesting. I would have appreciated a bit more organization to the study material.
He has done a lot of interesting things and has some great stories!

I would say it's an overview of how different infectious diseases are spread, and how this spread is changing due to a variety of factors. I would recommend it. I think this class contains the sort of knowledge that more people need to have.
This class could have been really interesting and insightful on zoonotic diseases. But it was all over the place and the professor did not seem invested in it.

Good way to get an overview of emerging and neglected infections; it is definitely NOT a course which is just memorization, there is a heavy focus on application and global context for all of the illnesses. Take it if that interests you.
Good course, learned a lot
it's a requirement. All EMDs have to take it.

It is a great class that is important to learn for infectious disease study even it can be a bit disorganized. The lecturers that come in can provide excellent information about their particularly specialty from West Nile Virus to phage therapy.
Should be better taught now that Amy Bei will be teaching the course. She was a guest lecturer and her presentation/lecturing was great!
